IRM 4.23.11.1. Deleted Overview. New subsection, Program Scope and Objectives. Rearranged existing IRM content to place information involving internal controls for a program IRM under this subsection to conform to the new rules to ensure that the program’s internal controls are adequately expressed in the IRM.
IRM 4.23.11.1.5. New subsection, Program Reports, provides information on the reporting of objectives and reports submitted to the Director, Specialty Examination Policy.

4.23.11.3. Formerly IRM 4.23.11.2(1). New agreement forms identiﬁed.

Updates are made to this section for procedural and technical changes. References to deﬁciency procedures deleted, as employment taxes are not subject to deﬁciency procedures.
IRM 4.23.11.10. Formerly IRM 4.23.11.9. Replaced reference to Form 2859 with Form 3198.
Updates are made to this section for procedural and technical changes. References to deﬁciency procedures deleted, as employment taxes are not subject to deﬁciency procedures.
This material supersedes IRM 4.23.11 dated February 7,
AUDIENCE

This section contains instructions and guidelines for all Large Business & International (LB&I), Tax Exempt/Governmental Entities (TE/GE), and Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) employees when with employment tax issues.
Prompt Action in Tax Underpayment and Overassessment Cases 4.23.11
) Purpose: This section details the steps for proposed employment tax payment and overassessment cases. Scope and (

) Audience: This section contains instructions and guidelines for all Large Business & International (LB&I), Tax Exempt/Government Entities (TE/GE), and Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) employees dealing with ment tax issues. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Specialty Examination Policy of the Small Self-Employed Division. (
) Program Owner: Program Manager - Employment Tax Policy. The mission Employment Tax Policy is to establish effective policies and procedures to support compliance with employment tax laws. (

) Primary Stakeholders: • Employment Tax – Workload Selection and Delivery :S:ETEGCS:EWSD) • Specialty Examination - Employment Tax (SE:S:E:SE:ET) • Specialty Examination Policy, Employment Tax Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:S- P:ET) • Other areas that are affected by these policies and procedures Appeals, Counsel, SB/SE Examination, LB&I, and TE/GE. (
) This section details the steps for tax assessment and overassessment (

) In accordance with the IRS continuing effort to reduce the Accounts able Dollar Inventory (ARDI) and Currently Not Collectible (CNC) Accounts, managers must strive for quality assessments and promote an increased emphasis on early collections. It is the general practice of the IRS to advance payments on agreed adjustments to employment tax returns and linquent returns secured during an examination. Managers will also provide information and assistance on the collection processing in all tax underpay- ment cases. (
) This IRM has been renamed Employment Tax - Prompt Action in Tax payment and Tax Overassessment Cases. The term deﬁciency does not generally apply to employment taxes. IRC

generally deﬁnes a as the excess of the correct amount of income tax, estate tax, or gift tax minus the tax amount shown on the return and amounts previously (or collected without assessment) as a deﬁciency, plus the amounts of made. In general, deﬁciency procedures are used when additional income, estate, or gift taxes, and/or related penalties are proposed. (
) Employment tax provisions are found at Internal Revenue Code Subtitle C: • Chapter
, Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA), • Chapter
, Railroad Retirement Tax Act (RRTA), • Chapter
, Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA), • Chapter
, Federal Income Tax Withholding (FITW), and • Chapter
, General Provisions relating to employment taxes and lection of income taxes at source.

able Dollar Inventory (ARDI) and Currently Not Collectible (CNC) Accounts, managers must strive for quality assessments and promote an increased emphasis on early collections. It is the general practice of the IRS to request advance payments on agreed adjustments to employment tax returns and de
linquent returns secured during an examination. Managers will also provide information and assistance on the collection processing in all tax underpay

Employment (
) The Employment Tax Program is governed by Policy Statements and other internal guidance that apply to all IRS personnel regardless of operating division. The Policy Statements found in IRM

, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policies of the Internal Revenue Service apply to all tax issues and examinations. Examiners should review these Policy State- ments to properly perform their examination duties. (

) A website, Delegation Orders by Process, located at https://www.irs.gov/ privacy-disclosure/delegation-orders-and-policy-statements-by-process rizes data contained in the applicable IRM sections under IRM
, relating Delegation Orders, in a single, electronic source. (
) IRM
provides Servicewide instructions for all operating divisions with employees involved with the correct ﬁling, reporting, and payment of ment taxes. IRM

serves as the foundation for consistent administration employment taxes by various IRS operating divisions. By providing one of authority for all operating divisions, the IRS greatly reduces philosophical and procedural inconsistencies. (
) Director, Specialty Examination Policy is responsible for the procedures and updates addressed in this IRM. (
) Director, Specialty Examination is the executive responsible for examination operational compliance. (
) Program Goals: The processes and procedures provided in this IRM are sistent with the objectives or goals for Employment Tax - Examination that and addressed in IRM
, Employment Tax Examination and for ment Tax Policy, found in IRM
, Employment Tax Policy. (
) Program Effectiveness: Program goals are measured with Employment Tax Embedded Quality Performance Reports that monitor whether quality are applied uniformly and consistently. (
) Annual Review: Employment Tax Policy - Program Manager is responsible reviewing the information in this IRM annually to ensure accuracy and consistent tax administration. (

) Program Reports: Information regarding the reporting of program objectives are included on, but not limited to, the following reports submitted to the Director, Specialty Examination Policy: • Headquarters Examination Monthly Brieﬁng, • Program Manager Monthly Brieﬁng, • Examination Operational Review, and • Business Performance Reviews. (
) The Quarterly Business Performance Review (BPR) provides updates on status of the Whistleblower claims in Operating Division SME status. (

) Examiners must request full payment in all agreed employment tax cases. examiner can accept payment by check or money order, or cash. If a desires to make payment by cash, Collection assistance in accepting the payment should be requested through the manager. Also, office locations have Wage and Investment (W&I) Division Field Assistance groups can in processing cash payments. (

) The taxpayer’s ability to pay is determined using a “tiered interview.” The “tiered interview” consists of the questions: a. Can you pay today? b. How much can you pay today? c. Can you pay at ﬁrst notice? d. Can you borrow to pay the ﬁrst notice? In each instance, the examiner should attempt to secure full payment. However, if the taxpayer indicates they will be able to pay the amount due upon receipt of the ﬁrst notice, no further requests for payments need to be made by the examiner. (
) If the taxpayer is not able to pay in full within
days of the ﬁrst notice, sideration should be given to an installment agreement, which should be coordinated with Collection. See IRM
, Examination Collectibility - ing Payment and IRM
, Examination’s Authority and Procedures. (
) If a taxpayer is bankrupt (“B” code on Form
, Examination Return Out Sheet) or is currently working with Collection on payment of taxes previously assessed (“C” code on Form
or Collection status “
”), tion will be consulted before proposing additional taxes. See IRM
, Examiner’s Responsibilities, for information on examiner responsibilities. (

, Interest-Free Adjustments General, and subsequent sections for further information on the free provision and deposit penalty rules. See IRM
, Returns (Forms

For agreed, unpaid employment tax cases worked in Area
(Specialty, Em- ployment Tax Examination) with a total tax greater than $

, examiners will: a. Initiate a collection referral using the Specialist Referral System (SRS). b. Provide available ﬁnancial information secured from the taxpayer during the audit via a separate, encrypted email to the Collection Area Coordina- tor.
(2) For agreed, unpaid employment tax cases worked in Area 212 (Specialty, Em- ployment Tax Examination) with a total tax greater than $100,000, examiners

a. Initiate a collection referral using the Specialist Referral System (SRS). b. Provide available ﬁnancial information secured from the taxpayer during the audit via a separate, encrypted email to the Collection Area tor. The SRS referral and additional information will be provided to the Collection Group Manager to address. Note: A “case” for employment tax purposes consists of all employment tax forms included in the taxpayer case ﬁle under examination, (e.g., Form(s)
, ployer’s Annual Federal Unemployment (FUTA) Tax Return, Forms
, Employer’s QUARTERLY Federal Tax Return, and other related returns). Related entities picked up as part of the package audit are considered separate cases. (

Caution: IRS personnel may not alter a waiver completed by a taxpayer or that a taxpayer execute a blank waiver.
Note: A timely-ﬁled waiver form is considered a valid claim for refund when a taxpayer agrees to an overassessment determined by the IRS.
) Pursuant to a November

memo from the Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement entitled “Revision of Policy for Use of Fax in Taxpayer Submissions”, the Policy for Use of Fax (fax policy) has been revised to eliminate the dollar ceiling for acceptance of consents to assess additional tax (including various Forms
and other consents) and taxpayer closing agreements (e.g., Form

, Closing Agreement on Final Determination Covering Speciﬁc Matters, or Classiﬁcation Settlement Program (CSP) agree- ments) received by fax. In addition, consents to extend the time to assess tax, which were not previously allowed by fax, are now acceptable. In all cases, the examiner must document in the case history:

Pursuant to a November 19, 2015 memo from the Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement entitled “Revision of Policy for Use of Fax in Taxpayer Submissions”, the Policy for Use of Fax (fax policy) has been to eliminate the dollar ceiling for acceptance of consents to assess additional tax (including various Forms 2504 and other consents) and taxpayer closing agreements (e.g., Form 906, Closing Agreement on Final Determination Covering Speciﬁc Matters, or Classiﬁcation Settlement Program (CSP) agree- ments) received by fax. In addition, consents to extend the time to assess tax, which were not previously allowed by fax, are now acceptable. In all cases,
examiner must document in the case history: • That taxpayer contact has been made, • The date of contact, and • The desire of the taxpayer to submit the document by fax. (

) If an error made in computing additional tax, overassessment, or penalty shown on a previously executed report/waiver reﬂects a tax greater than the correct amount, a corrected report showing the lesser amount will be prepared. A copy should be given to the taxpayer; however, no signature on the new report/waiver is required. Note on the corrected report, “Refer to the taxpayer’s signature on the report dated (date)”. See IRM
, Corrected Reports. (

) If an error is made on the report/waiver that reﬂects a tax less than the correct amount, the examiner has two alternatives. The examiner may prepare a corrected report and solicit a new waiver or the case may be processed for the amount shown on the original executed report/waiver if it falls under the Error Tolerance levels of SB/SE Delegation Order
The group, or function dis- covering the error, will prepare a memo to Centralized Case Processing (CCP) signed by a person authorized by the delegation order. See IRM
and SB/SE Delegation Order
, Error Tolerance Levels at: http://mysbse.web.irs. gov/opsupport/hc/facilitiesorganizationalsupport/orgsupportteam/imd/delorders/functional/examination/
aspx

If an error is made on the report/waiver that reﬂects a tax less than the correct amount, the examiner has two alternatives. The examiner may prepare a corrected report and solicit a new waiver or the case may be processed for the amount shown on the original executed report/waiver if it falls under the Error Tolerance levels of SB/SE Delegation Order 4.41. The group, or function dis- covering the error, will prepare a memo to Centralized Case Processing (CCP) signed by a person authorized by the delegation order. See IRM 4.10.8.13 and SB/SE Delegation Order 4.41, Error Tolerance Levels at: http://mysbse.web.irs.

) When the correction of an error results in the increase of tax not processed under (

) above for any period shown on a waiver, a supplemental waiver be secured for the difference between the tax or penalty, as corrected, and amount shown on the original waiver. The supplemental waiver will be identiﬁed as such and stapled on top of the original waiver, and the case will be processed in the usual manner. If the correction of an error results in the decrease of an overassessment not processed under (
) above, a new will be secured for the amount of the corrected overassessment. (
) When a waiver covers multiple periods, the rules in (
) through (

) above be applied separately to each period involved and not to the net effect of the waiver. For example, if a waiver shows additional taxes for each of two periods, but corrections result in a substantial tax increase for one period a substantial tax reduction for the other period, a new waiver should be solicited even though the net effect of the corrections may favor the (
) A remittance may be a payment of tax or a deposit. A payment may be an advance payment or subsequent payment. Deposits (
) An advance payment is made before an assessment; it may be received an examiner solicits payment of the proposed tax in agreed ﬁeld and office amination cases. See IRM
, Examination, Collectibility, Soliciting Payment. The examiner will not solicit a remittance from a taxpayer until the examination is completed and an agreement secured. (
) A subsequent payment is made after an assessment. All remittances with delinquent returns secured by examiners are subsequent payments. (
) A taxpayer may offer a remittance prior to the completion of the examination as a means of stopping the accrual of interest: a. IRC

, the employer can make a cash bond deposit with the IRS to stop any interest from accruing and still preserve the em- ployer’s right to go to Tax Court. See IRM
, Interest-Free Adjustments, at (

) When a case involves restricted interest, the examiner will not solicit the interest due. If the taxpayer desires to make full payment of the balance the examiner will check the “Restricted Interest” box on the Form
and advise the taxpayer that the restricted interest provisions apply and cannot computed at this time; the interest will be computed at closing by a tax examiner in CCP. See IRM
, Restricted Interest.
) When the correction of an error results in the increase of tax not processed under (

) above for any period shown on a waiver, a supplemental waiver will be secured for the difference between the tax or penalty, as corrected, and amount shown on the original waiver. The supplemental waiver will be clearly identiﬁed as such and stapled on top of the original waiver, and the case will be processed in the usual manner. If the correction of an error results in the decrease of an overassessment not processed under (
) above, a new waiver will be secured for the amount of the corrected overassessment. (
) When a waiver covers multiple periods, the rules in (
) through (

) above be applied separately to each period involved and not to the net effect of the waiver. For example, if a waiver shows additional taxes for each of two periods, but corrections result in a substantial tax increase for one period and a substantial tax reduction for the other period, a new waiver should be solicited even though the net effect of the corrections may favor the taxpayer.

A remittance may be a payment of tax or a deposit. A payment may be an advance payment or subsequent payment. An advance payment is made before an assessment; it may be received an examiner solicits payment of the proposed tax in agreed ﬁeld and office amination cases. See IRM

, Examination, Collectibility, Soliciting Payment. The examiner will not solicit a remittance from a taxpayer until the examination is completed and an agreement secured. A subsequent payment is made after an assessment. All remittances with delinquent returns secured by examiners are subsequent payments. deposit - discussed at IRM

) When a case involves restricted interest, the examiner will not solicit the interest due. If the taxpayer desires to make full payment of the balance due, the examiner will check the “Restricted Interest” box on the Form
and advise the taxpayer that the restricted interest provisions apply and cannot be computed at this time; the interest will be computed at closing by a tax examiner in CCP. See IRM
, Restricted Interest.

) The assessment of additional tax (except in bankruptcy and receivership ceedings) falls within the following categories: a. Quick Assessment: A quick assessment is made if the statutory for assessing an additional tax or an agreed tax proposal is about to expire. See IRM

for procedures on making a Quick Assess- ment. b. Prompt Assessment: A prompt assessment is made if collection appears to be at risk and the intention is to protect the government’s interest and revenue. See IRM
for procedures on making a Prompt Assessment. Note: For more information on Quick/Prompt Assessments, refer to

, AIMS Procedures and Processing Instructions - Quick As- sessments. c. Jeopardy Assessment: A jeopardy assessment is made in situations where, prior to the assessment of tax, it is determined that collection of such tax would be endangered if regular assessment and collection cedures are followed. IRC
, “Jeopardy Assessments of Taxes Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The IRC provides that, under certain conditions, interest on underpayments and overpayments of tax is prohibited or limited to speciﬁc accrual periods. These special interest accrual periods are different than those that would result if the underpayments and overpayments were subject to the regular interest provisions of IRC
, “Interest on Underpayment, Nonpayment, or Exten- sions of Time for Payment, of Tax”, and IRC
, “Interest on Overpayments.” These prohibitions give rise to the term “restricted interest.” (
) The sections of the Code which authorize the restriction of interest on employ- ment taxes are IRC
(a) (underpayments) and IRC
(a) and (d), (overpayments). (

) A prompt assessment is a manually processed assessment of a secured where collection appears to be at risk and the intention is to proceed with col- lection action immediately upon request of the assessment. A prompt assessment may only be requested when prompt collection action is to protect the government’s interest and revenue. (
) If the taxpayer is quickly placing property beyond the reach of the collection action may be taken, even though the
-day notice and demand period and the

)(A) requires written approval from Counsel for a jeopardy levy. (

) Jeopardy assessments are made in situations where, prior to the assessment of tax, it is determined that collection of such tax would be endangered if regular assessment and collection procedures are followed. (
) All jeopardy assessments must be in full compliance with Policy Statement
, found at IRM

, which advises: “Jeopardy assessments should be used sparingly and care should be taken to avoid excessive and able assessments.” At least one of the following conditions must exist: a. The taxpayer is, or appears to be, preparing to quickly depart from the United States or to conceal himself/herself, b.
